Removes the first occurrence of the given pointer from the pointer array. The last element in the array is used to fill in the space, so this function does not preserve the order of the array. But it is faster than g_ptr_array_remove(). If @array has a non-%NULL #GDestroyNotify function it is called for the removed element.
It returns %TRUE if the pointer was removed, or %FALSE if the pointer was not found.
function.return: %TRUE if the pointer was found in the array.

function.name: g_ptr_array_remove_index
function.description: Removes the pointer at the given index from the pointer array. The following elements are moved down one place. If @array has a non-%NULL #GDestroyNotify function it is called for the removed element.

parameter.name: index_
parameter.parameter_description: the index of the pointer to remove.

function.return: the pointer which was removed.

function.name: g_ptr_array_remove_index_fast
function.description: Removes the pointer at the given index from the pointer array. The last element in the array is used to fill in the space, so this function does not preserve the order of the array. But it is faster than g_ptr_array_remove_index(). If @array has a non-%NULL #GDestroyNotify function it is called for the removed element.

parameter.name: index_
parameter.parameter_description: the index of the pointer to remove.

function.return: the pointer which was removed.

function.name: g_ptr_array_remove_range
function.description:
Removes the given number of pointers starting at the given index from a #GPtrArray. The following elements are moved to close the gap. If @array has a non-%NULL #GDestroyNotify function it is called for the removed elements.
Since: 2.4

parameter.name: index_
parameter.parameter_description: the index of the first pointer to remove.

parameter.name: length
parameter.parameter_description: the number of pointers to remove.

function.name: g_ptr_array_set_free_func
function.description:
Sets a function for freeing each element when @array is destroyed either via g_ptr_array_unref(), when g_ptr_array_free() is called with @free_segment set to %TRUE or when removing elements.
Since: 2.22

parameter.name: element_free_func
parameter.parameter_description: A function to free elements with destroy @array or %NULL.

function.name: g_ptr_array_set_size
function.description: Sets the size of the array. When making the array larger, newly-added elements will be set to %NULL. When making it smaller, if @array has a non-%NULL #GDestroyNotify function then it will be called for the removed elements.

parameter.name: length
parameter.parameter_description: the new length of the pointer array.

function.name: g_ptr_array_sized_new
function.description: Creates a new #GPtrArray with @reserved_size pointers preallocated and a reference count of 1. This avoids frequent reallocation, if you are going to add many pointers to the array. Note however that the size of the array is still 0.
function.return: the new #GPtrArray.

function.name: g_ptr_array_sort
function.description:
Sorts the array, using @compare_func which should be a qsort()-style comparison function (returns less than zero for first arg is less than second arg, zero for equal, greater than zero if irst arg is greater than second arg).
If two array elements compare equal, their order in the sorted array is undefined.
<note><para>The comparison function for g_ptr_array_sort() doesn't take the pointers from the array as arguments, it takes pointers to the pointers in the array.</para></note>

function.name: g_ptr_array_sort_with_data
function.description:
Like g_ptr_array_sort(), but the comparison function has an extra user data argument.
<note><para>The comparison function for g_ptr_array_sort_with_data() doesn't take the pointers from the array as arguments, it takes pointers to the pointers in the array.</para></note>

function.name: g_ptr_array_unref
function.description:
Atomically decrements the reference count of @array by one. If the reference count drops to 0, the effect is the same as calling g_ptr_array_free() with @free_segment set to %TRUE. This function is MT-safe and may be called from any thread.
Since: 2.22

function.name: g_qsort_with_data
function.description: This is just like the standard C qsort() function, but the comparison routine accepts a user data argument.

function.name: g_quark_from_static_string
function.description:
Gets the #GQuark identifying the given (static) string. If the string does not currently have an associated #GQuark, a new #GQuark is created, linked to the given string.
Note that this function is identical to g_quark_from_string() except that if a new #GQuark is created the string itself is used rather than a copy. This saves memory, but can only be used if the string will <emphasis>always</emphasis> exist. It can be used with statically allocated strings in the main program, but not with statically allocated memory in dynamically loaded modules, if you expect to ever unload the module again (e.g. do not use this function in GTK+ theme engines).
function.return: the #GQuark identifying the string, or 0 if @string is %NULL.

function.name: g_quark_from_string
function.description: Gets the #GQuark identifying the given string. If the string does not currently have an associated #GQuark, a new #GQuark is created, using a copy of the string.
function.return: the #GQuark identifying the string, or 0 if @string is %NULL.

function.name: g_quark_to_string
function.description: Gets the string associated with the given #GQuark.
function.return: the string associated with the #GQuark.

function.name: g_quark_try_string
function.description:
Gets the #GQuark associated with the given string, or 0 if string is %NULL or it has no associated #GQuark.
If you want the GQuark to be created if it doesn't already exist, use g_quark_from_string() or g_quark_from_static_string().
function.return: the #GQuark associated with the string, or 0 if @string is %NULL or there is no #GQuark associated with it.

function.name: g_queue_clear
function.description:
Removes all the elements in @queue. If queue elements contain dynamically-allocated memory, they should be freed first.
Since: 2.14

function.name: g_queue_copy
function.description:
Copies a @queue. Note that is a shallow copy. If the elements in the queue consist of pointers to data, the pointers are copied, but the actual data is not.
Since: 2.4
function.return: A copy of @queue

function.name: g_queue_delete_link

parameter.name: link_
parameter.parameter_description: a #GList link that <emphasis>must</emphasis> be part of @queue

function.name: g_queue_find
function.description:
Finds the first link in @queue which contains @data.
Since: 2.4
function.return: The first link in @queue which contains @data.

function.name: g_queue_find_custom
function.description:
Finds an element in a #GQueue, using a supplied function to find the desired element. It iterates over the queue, calling the given function which should return 0 when the desired element is found. The function takes two gconstpointer arguments, the #GQueue element's data as the first argument and the given user data as the second argument.
Since: 2.4

parameter.name: func
parameter.parameter_description: a #GCompareFunc to call for each element. It should return 0 when the desired element is found

function.return: The found link, or %NULL if it wasn't found

function.name: g_queue_foreach
function.description:
Calls @func for each element in the queue passing @user_data to the function.
Since: 2.4

parameter.name: func
parameter.parameter_description: the function to call for each element's data

function.name: g_queue_free
g_queue_get_length
function.description:
Returns the number of items in @queue.
Since: 2.4
function.return: The number of items in @queue.

function.name: g_queue_index
function.description:
Returns the position of the first element in @queue which contains @data.
Since: 2.4
function.return: The position of the first element in @queue which contains @data, or -1 if no element in @queue contains @data.

function.name: g_queue_init
function.description:
A statically-allocated #GQueue must be initialized with this function before it can be used. Alternatively you can initialize it with #G_QUEUE_INIT. It is not necessary to initialize queues created with g_queue_new().
Since: 2.14

function.name: g_queue_insert_after

parameter.name: sibling
parameter.parameter_description: a #GList link that <emphasis>must</emphasis> be part of @queue

function.name: g_queue_insert_before

parameter.name: sibling
parameter.parameter_description: a #GList link that <emphasis>must</emphasis> be part of @queue

function.name: g_queue_insert_sorted
function.description:
Inserts @data into @queue using @func to determine the new position.
Since: 2.4

parameter.name: func
parameter.parameter_description: the #GCompareDataFunc used to compare elements in the queue. It is called with two elements of the @queue and @user_data. It should return 0 if the elements are equal, a negative value if the first element comes before the second, and a positive value if the second element comes before the first.

function.name: g_queue_is_empty
function.description: Returns %TRUE if the queue is empty.
function.return: %TRUE if the queue is empty.

function.name: g_queue_link_index
function.description:
Returns the position of @link_ in @queue.
Since: 2.4
function.return: The position of @link_, or -1 if the link is not part of @queue

function.name: g_queue_new
function.description: Creates a new #GQueue.
function.return: a new #GQueue.

function.name: g_queue_peek_head
function.description: Returns the first element of the queue.
function.return: the data of the first element in the queue, or %NULL if the queue is empty.

function.name: g_queue_peek_head_link
function.description:
Returns the first link in @queue
Since: 2.4
function.return: the first link in @queue, or %NULL if @queue is empty

function.name: g_queue_peek_nth
function.description:
Returns the @n'th element of @queue.
Since: 2.4
function.return: The data for the @n'th element of @queue, or %NULL if @n is off the end of @queue.

function.name: g_queue_peek_nth_link
function.description:
Returns the link at the given position
Since: 2.4
function.return: The link at the @n'th position, or %NULL if @n is off the end of the list

function.name: g_queue_peek_tail
function.description: Returns the last element of the queue.
function.return: the data of the last element in the queue, or %NULL if the queue is empty.

function.name: g_queue_peek_tail_link
function.description:
Returns the last link @queue.
Since: 2.4

function.name: g_queue_pop_tail_link

function.name: g_queue_remove_all

Remove all elements whose data equals @data from @queue.

function.name: g_queue_reverse

Reverses the order of the items in @queue.

function.name: g_queue_sort

Sorts @queue using @compare_func.

parameter.parameter_description: the #GCompareDataFunc used to sort @queue. This function is passed two elements of the queue and should return 0 if they are equal, a negative value if the first comes before the second, and a positive value if the second comes before the first.

function.name: g_queue_unlink

function.name: g_realloc
function.description: Reallocates the memory pointed to by @mem, so that it now has space for @n_bytes bytes of memory. It returns the new address of the memory, which may have been moved. @mem may be %NULL, in which case it's considered to have zero-length. @n_bytes may be 0, in which case %NULL will be returned and @mem will be freed unless it is %NULL.

parameter.name: n_bytes
parameter.parameter_description: new size of the memory in bytes

function.return: the new address of the allocated memory

function.name: g_realloc_n
function.description:
This function is similar to g_realloc(), allocating (@n_blocks * @n_block_bytes) bytes, but care is taken to detect possible overflow during multiplication.
Since: 2.24

parameter.name: n_blocks
parameter.parameter_description: the number of blocks to allocate

parameter.name: n_block_bytes
parameter.parameter_description: the size of each block in bytes

function.return: the new address of the allocated memory

function.name: g_regex_check_replacement
function.description:
Checks whether @replacement is a valid replacement string (see g_regex_replace()), i.e. that all escape sequences in it are valid.
If @has_references is not %NULL then @replacement is checked for pattern references. For instance, replacement text 'foo\n' does not contain references and may be evaluated without information about actual match, but '\0\1' (whole match followed by first subpattern) requires valid #GMatchInfo object.
Since: 2.14

parameter.name: has_references
parameter.parameter_description: location to store information about references in @replacement or %NULL

function.return: whether @replacement is a valid replacement string

function.name: g_regex_escape_string

parameter.name: length
parameter.parameter_description: the length of @string, or -1 if @string is nul-terminated

function.return: a newly-allocated escaped string

function.name: g_regex_get_capture_count
function.description:
Returns the number of capturing subpatterns in the pattern.
Since: 2.14
function.return: the number of capturing subpatterns

function.name: g_regex_get_compile_flags
function.description:
Returns the compile options that @regex was created with.
Since: 2.26
function.return: flags from #GRegexCompileFlags

function.name: g_regex_get_match_flags
function.description:
Returns the match options that @regex was created with.
Since: 2.26
function.return: flags from #GRegexMatchFlags

function.name: g_regex_get_max_backref
function.description:
Returns the number of the highest back reference in the pattern, or 0 if the pattern does not contain back references.
Since: 2.14
function.return: the number of the highest back reference

function.name: g_regex_get_pattern
function.description:
Gets the pattern string associated with @regex, i.e. a copy of the string passed to g_regex_new().
Since: 2.14
function.return: the pattern of @regex

function.name: g_regex_get_string_number
function.description:
Retrieves the number of the subexpression named @name.
Since: 2.14
function.return: The number of the subexpression or -1 if @name does not exists

function.name: g_regex_match

parameter.name: string
parameter.parameter_description: the string to scan for matches

parameter.name: match_info
parameter.parameter_description: pointer to location where to store the #GMatchInfo, or %NULL if you do not need it

function.return: %TRUE is the string matched, %FALSE otherwise

function.name: g_regex_match_all
function.description:
Using the standard algorithm for regular expression matching only the longest match in the string is retrieved. This function uses a different algorithm so it can retrieve all the possible matches. For more documentation see g_regex_match_all_full().
A #GMatchInfo structure, used to get information on the match, is stored in @match_info if not %NULL. Note that if @match_info is not %NULL then it is created even if the function returns %FALSE, i.e. you must free it regardless if regular expression actually matched.
@string is not copied and is used in #GMatchInfo internally. If you use any #GMatchInfo method (except g_match_info_free()) after freeing or modifying @string then the behaviour is undefined.
Since: 2.14

parameter.name: string
parameter.parameter_description: the string to scan for matches

parameter.name: match_info
parameter.parameter_description: pointer to location where to store the #GMatchInfo, or %NULL if you do not need it

function.return: %TRUE is the string matched, %FALSE otherwise

function.name: g_regex_match_all_full
function.description:
Using the standard algorithm for regular expression matching only the longest match in the string is retrieved, it is not possibile to obtain all the available matches. For instance matching "<a> <b> <c>" against the pattern "<.*>" you get "<a> <b> <c>".
This function uses a different algorithm (called DFA, i.e. deterministic finite automaton), so it can retrieve all the possible matches, all starting at the same point in the string. For instance matching "<a> <b> <c>" against the pattern "<.*>" you would obtain three matches: "<a> <b> <c>", "<a> <b>" and "<a>".
The number of matched strings is retrieved using g_match_info_get_match_count(). To obtain the matched strings and their position you can use, respectively, g_match_info_fetch() and g_match_info_fetch_pos(). Note that the strings are returned in reverse order of length; that is, the longest matching string is given first.
Note that the DFA algorithm is slower than the standard one and it is not able to capture substrings, so backreferences do not work.
Setting @start_position differs from just passing over a shortened string and setting #G_REGEX_MATCH_NOTBOL in the case of a pattern that begins with any kind of lookbehind assertion, such as "\b".
A #GMatchInfo structure, used to get information on the match, is stored in @match_info if not %NULL. Note that if @match_info is not %NULL then it is created even if the function returns %FALSE, i.e. you must free it regardless if regular expression actually matched.
@string is not copied and is used in #GMatchInfo internally. If you use any #GMatchInfo method (except g_match_info_free()) after freeing or modifying @string then the behaviour is undefined.
Since: 2.14

parameter.name: string
parameter.parameter_description: the string to scan for matches

parameter.name: string_len
parameter.parameter_description: the length of @string, or -1 if @string is nul-terminated

parameter.name: start_position
parameter.parameter_description: starting index of the string to match

parameter.name: match_info
parameter.parameter_description: pointer to location where to store the #GMatchInfo, or %NULL if you do not need it

parameter.name: error
parameter.parameter_description: location to store the error occuring, or %NULL to ignore errors

function.return: %TRUE is the string matched, %FALSE otherwise

function.name: g_regex_match_full

parameter.name: string
parameter.parameter_description: the string to scan for matches

parameter.name: string_len
parameter.parameter_description: the length of @string, or -1 if @string is nul-terminated

parameter.name: start_position
parameter.parameter_description: starting index of the string to match

parameter.name: match_info
parameter.parameter_description: pointer to location where to store the #GMatchInfo, or %NULL if you do not need it

parameter.name: error
parameter.parameter_description: location to store the error occuring, or %NULL to ignore errors

function.return: %TRUE is the string matched, %FALSE otherwise

function.name: g_regex_match_simple
function.description:
Scans for a match in @string for @pattern.
This function is equivalent to g_regex_match() but it does not require to compile the pattern with g_regex_new(), avoiding some lines of code when you need just to do a match without extracting substrings, capture counts, and so on.
If this function is to be called on the same @pattern more than once, it's more efficient to compile the pattern once with g_regex_new() and then use g_regex_match().
Since: 2.14

parameter.name: string
parameter.parameter_description: the string to scan for matches

parameter.name: compile_options
parameter.parameter_description: compile options for the regular expression, or 0

function.return: %TRUE if the string matched, %FALSE otherwise

function.name: g_regex_new
function.description:
Compiles the regular expression to an internal form, and does the initial setup of the #GRegex structure.
Since: 2.14

parameter.name: compile_options
parameter.parameter_description: compile options for the regular expression, or 0

parameter.name: match_options
parameter.parameter_description: match options for the regular expression, or 0

function.return: a #GRegex structure. Call g_regex_unref() when you are done with it

function.name: g_regex_ref
function.description:
Increases reference count of @regex by 1.
Since: 2.14
function.return: @regex

function.name: g_regex_replace
function.description:
Replaces all occurrences of the pattern in @regex with the replacement text. Backreferences of the form '\number' or '\g<number>' in the replacement text are interpolated by the number-th captured subexpression of the match, '\g<name>' refers to the captured subexpression with the given name. '\0' refers to the complete match, but '\0' followed by a number is the octal representation of a character. To include a literal '\' in the replacement, write '\\'. There are also escapes that changes the case of the following text:
<variablelist> <varlistentry><term>\l</term> <listitem> <para>Convert to lower case the next character</para> </listitem> </varlistentry> <varlistentry><term>\u</term> <listitem> <para>Convert to upper case the next character</para> </listitem> </varlistentry> <varlistentry><term>\L</term> <listitem> <para>Convert to lower case till \E</para> </listitem> </varlistentry> <varlistentry><term>\U</term> <listitem> <para>Convert to upper case till \E</para> </listitem> </varlistentry> <varlistentry><term>\E</term> <listitem> <para>End case modification</para> </listitem> </varlistentry> </variablelist>
If you do not need to use backreferences use g_regex_replace_literal().
The @replacement string must be UTF-8 encoded even if #G_REGEX_RAW was passed to g_regex_new(). If you want to use not UTF-8 encoded stings you can use g_regex_replace_literal().
Setting @start_position differs from just passing over a shortened string and setting #G_REGEX_MATCH_NOTBOL in the case of a pattern that begins with any kind of lookbehind assertion, such as "\b".
Since: 2.14

parameter.name: string
parameter.parameter_description: the string to perform matches against

parameter.name: string_len
parameter.parameter_description: the length of @string, or -1 if @string is nul-terminated

parameter.name: start_position
parameter.parameter_description: starting index of the string to match

parameter.name: replacement
parameter.parameter_description: text to replace each match with

parameter.name: error
parameter.parameter_description: location to store the error occuring, or %NULL to ignore errors

function.return: a newly allocated string containing the replacements

function.name: g_regex_replace_eval

parameter.name: string_len
parameter.parameter_description: the length of @string, or -1 if @string is nul-terminated

parameter.name: start_position
parameter.parameter_description: starting index of the string to match

parameter.name: eval
parameter.parameter_description: a function to call for each match

parameter.name: user_data
parameter.parameter_description: user data to pass to the function

parameter.name: error
parameter.parameter_description: location to store the error occuring, or %NULL to ignore errors

function.return: a newly allocated string containing the replacements

function.name: g_regex_replace_literal
function.description:
Replaces all occurrences of the pattern in @regex with the replacement text. @replacement is replaced literally, to include backreferences use g_regex_replace().
Setting @start_position differs from just passing over a shortened string and setting #G_REGEX_MATCH_NOTBOL in the case of a pattern that begins with any kind of lookbehind assertion, such as "\b".
Since: 2.14

parameter.name: string
parameter.parameter_description: the string to perform matches against

parameter.name: string_len
parameter.parameter_description: the length of @string, or -1 if @string is nul-terminated

parameter.name: start_position
parameter.parameter_description: starting index of the string to match

parameter.name: replacement
parameter.parameter_description: text to replace each match with

parameter.name: error
parameter.parameter_description: location to store the error occuring, or %NULL to ignore errors

function.return: a newly allocated string containing the replacements

function.name: g_regex_split
function.description:
Breaks the string on the pattern, and returns an array of the tokens. If the pattern contains capturing parentheses, then the text for each of the substrings will also be returned. If the pattern does not match anywhere in the string, then the whole string is returned as the first token.
As a special case, the result of splitting the empty string "" is an empty vector, not a vector containing a single string. The reason for this special case is that being able to represent a empty vector is typically more useful than consistent handling of empty elements. If you do need to represent empty elements, you'll need to check for the empty string before calling this function.
A pattern that can match empty strings splits @string into separate characters wherever it matches the empty string between characters. For example splitting "ab c" using as a separator "\s*", you will get "a", "b" and "c".
Since: 2.14

parameter.name: string
parameter.parameter_description: the string to split with the pattern

function.return: a %NULL-terminated gchar ** array. Free it using g_strfreev()

function.name: g_regex_split_full
function.description:
Breaks the string on the pattern, and returns an array of the tokens. If the pattern contains capturing parentheses, then the text for each of the substrings will also be returned. If the pattern does not match anywhere in the string, then the whole string is returned as the first token.
As a special case, the result of splitting the empty string "" is an empty vector, not a vector containing a single string. The reason for this special case is that being able to represent a empty vector is typically more useful than consistent handling of empty elements. If you do need to represent empty elements, you'll need to check for the empty string before calling this function.
A pattern that can match empty strings splits @string into separate characters wherever it matches the empty string between characters. For example splitting "ab c" using as a separator "\s*", you will get "a", "b" and "c".
Setting @start_position differs from just passing over a shortened string and setting #G_REGEX_MATCH_NOTBOL in the case of a pattern that begins with any kind of lookbehind assertion, such as "\b".
Since: 2.14

parameter.name: string
parameter.parameter_description: the string to split with the pattern

parameter.name: string_len
parameter.parameter_description: the length of @string, or -1 if @string is nul-terminated

parameter.name: start_position
parameter.parameter_description: starting index of the string to match

parameter.name: max_tokens
parameter.parameter_description: the maximum number of tokens to split @string into. If this is less than 1, the string is split completely

function.return: a %NULL-terminated gchar ** array. Free it using g_strfreev()

function.name: g_regex_split_simple
function.description:
Breaks the string on the pattern, and returns an array of the tokens. If the pattern contains capturing parentheses, then the text for each of the substrings will also be returned. If the pattern does not match anywhere in the string, then the whole string is returned as the first token.
This function is equivalent to g_regex_split() but it does not require to compile the pattern with g_regex_new(), avoiding some lines of code when you need just to do a split without extracting substrings, capture counts, and so on.
If this function is to be called on the same @pattern more than once, it's more efficient to compile the pattern once with g_regex_new() and then use g_regex_split().
As a special case, the result of splitting the empty string "" is an empty vector, not a vector containing a single string. The reason for this special case is that being able to represent a empty vector is typically more useful than consistent handling of empty elements. If you do need to represent empty elements, you'll need to check for the empty string before calling this function.
A pattern that can match empty strings splits @string into separate characters wherever it matches the empty string between characters. For example splitting "ab c" using as a separator "\s*", you will get "a", "b" and "c".
Since: 2.14

parameter.name: string
parameter.parameter_description: the string to scan for matches

parameter.name: compile_options
parameter.parameter_description: compile options for the regular expression, or 0

function.return: a %NULL-terminated array of strings. Free it using g_strfreev()

function.name: g_regex_unref
function.description:
Decreases reference count of @regex by 1. When reference count drops to zero, it frees all the memory associated with the regex structure.
Since: 2.14

function.name: g_relation_count
function.description:
Returns the number of tuples in a #GRelation that have the given value in the given field.
Deprecated: 2.26: Rarely used API

parameter.name: field
parameter.parameter_description: the field of each record to match.

function.return: the number of matches.

function.name: g_relation_delete
function.description:
Deletes any records from a #GRelation that have the given key value in the given field.
Deprecated: 2.26: Rarely used API

parameter.name: field
parameter.parameter_description: the field of each record to match.

function.return: the number of records deleted.

function.name: g_relation_destroy
function.description:
Destroys the #GRelation, freeing all memory allocated. However, it does not free memory allocated for the tuple data, so you should free that first if appropriate.
Deprecated: 2.26: Rarely used API

function.name: g_relation_exists
function.description:
Returns %TRUE if a record with the given values exists in a #GRelation. Note that the values are compared directly, so that, for example, two copies of the same string will not match.
Deprecated: 2.26: Rarely used API

parameter.name: Varargs
parameter.parameter_description: the fields of the record to compare. The number must match the number of fields in the #GRelation.

function.return: %TRUE if a record matches.

function.name: g_relation_index
function.description:
Creates an index on the given field. Note that this must be called before any records are added to the #GRelation.
Deprecated: 2.26: Rarely used API

parameter.name: field
parameter.parameter_description: the field to index, counting from 0.

parameter.name: hash_func
parameter.parameter_description: a function to produce a hash value from the field data.

parameter.name: key_equal_func
parameter.parameter_description: a function to compare two values of the given field.

function.name: g_relation_insert
function.description:
Inserts a record into a #GRelation.
Deprecated: 2.26: Rarely used API

parameter.name: Varargs
parameter.parameter_description: the fields of the record to add. These must match the number of fields in the #GRelation, and of type #gpointer or #gconstpointer.

function.name: g_relation_new
function.description:
Creates a new #GRelation with the given number of fields. Note that currently the number of fields must be 2.
Deprecated: 2.26: Rarely used API
function.return: a new #GRelation.

function.name: g_relation_print
function.description:
Outputs information about all records in a #GRelation, as well as the indexes. It is for debugging.
Deprecated: 2.26: Rarely used API

function.name: g_relation_select
function.description:
Returns all of the tuples which have the given key in the given field. Use g_tuples_index() to access the returned records. The returned records should be freed with g_tuples_destroy().
Deprecated: 2.26: Rarely used API

parameter.name: field
parameter.parameter_description: the field of each record to match.

function.return: the records (tuples) that matched.

function.name: g_reload_user_special_dirs_cache
function.description:
Resets the cache used for g_get_user_special_dir(), so that the latest on-disk version is used. Call this only if you just changed the data on disk yourself.
Due to threadsafety issues this may cause leaking of strings that were previously returned from g_get_user_special_dir() that can't be freed. We ensure to only leak the data for the directories that actually changed value though.
Since: 2.22

function.name: g_remove
function.description:
A wrapper for the POSIX remove() function. The remove() function deletes a name from the filesystem.
See your C library manual for more details about how remove() works on your system. On Unix, remove() removes also directories, as it calls unlink() for files and rmdir() for directories. On Windows, although remove() in the C library only works for files, this function tries first remove() and then if that fails rmdir(), and thus works for both files and directories. Note however, that on Windows, it is in general not possible to remove a file that is open to some process, or mapped into memory.
If this function fails on Windows you can't infer too much from the errno value. rmdir() is tried regardless of what caused remove() to fail. Any errno value set by remove() will be overwritten by that set by rmdir().
Since: 2.6

parameter.name: filename
parameter.parameter_description: a pathname in the GLib file name encoding (UTF-8 on Windows)

function.return: 0 if the file was successfully removed, -1 if an error occurred

function.name: g_rename
function.description:
A wrapper for the POSIX rename() function. The rename() function renames a file, moving it between directories if required.
See your C library manual for more details about how rename() works on your system. It is not possible in general on Windows to rename a file that is open to some process.
Since: 2.6

parameter.name: oldfilename
parameter.parameter_description: a pathname in the GLib file name encoding (UTF-8 on Windows)

parameter.name: newfilename
parameter.parameter_description: a pathname in the GLib file name encoding

function.return: 0 if the renaming succeeded, -1 if an error occurred

function.name: g_rmdir
function.description:
A wrapper for the POSIX rmdir() function. The rmdir() function deletes a directory from the filesystem.
See your C library manual for more details about how rmdir() works on your system.
Since: 2.6

parameter.name: filename
parameter.parameter_description: a pathname in the GLib file name encoding (UTF-8 on Windows)

function.return: 0 if the directory was successfully removed, -1 if an error occurred

function.name: g_sequence_append
function.description:
Adds a new item to the end of @seq.
Since: 2.14

parameter.name: data
parameter.parameter_description: the data for the new item

function.return: an iterator pointing to the new item

function.name: g_sequence_foreach
function.description:
Calls @func for each item in the sequence passing @user_data to the function.
Since: 2.14

parameter.name: func
parameter.parameter_description: the function to call for each item in @seq

function.name: g_sequence_foreach_range
g_sequence_free
function.description:
Frees the memory allocated for @seq. If @seq has a data destroy function associated with it, that function is called on all items in @seq.
Since: 2.14

function.name: g_sequence_get
function.description:
Returns the data that @iter points to.
Since: 2.14
function.return: the data that @iter points to

function.name: g_sequence_get_begin_iter
function.description:
Returns the begin iterator for @seq.
Since: 2.14
function.return: the begin iterator for @seq.

function.name: g_sequence_get_end_iter
function.description:
Returns the end iterator for @seg
Since: 2.14
function.return: the end iterator for @seq

function.name: g_sequence_get_iter_at_pos
function.description:
Returns the iterator at position @pos. If @pos is negative or larger than the number of items in @seq, the end iterator is returned.
Since: 2.14

parameter.name: pos
parameter.parameter_description: a position in @seq, or -1 for the end.

function.return: The #GSequenceIter at position @pos

function.name: g_sequence_get_length
function.description:
Returns the length of @seq
Since: 2.14
function.return: the length of @seq

function.name: g_sequence_insert_before
function.description:
Inserts a new item just before the item pointed to by @iter.
Since: 2.14

parameter.name: data
parameter.parameter_description: the data for the new item

function.return: an iterator pointing to the new item

function.name: g_sequence_insert_sorted
function.description:
Inserts @data into @sequence using @func to determine the new position. The sequence must already be sorted according to @cmp_func; otherwise the new position of @data is undefined.
Since: 2.14

parameter.name: cmp_func
parameter.parameter_description: the #GCompareDataFunc used to compare items in the sequence. It is called with two items of the @seq and @user_data. It should return 0 if the items are equal, a negative value if the first item comes before the second, and a positive value if the second item comes before the first.

function.return: a #GSequenceIter pointing to the new item.

function.name: g_sequence_insert_sorted_iter
function.description:
Like g_sequence_insert_sorted(), but uses a #GSequenceIterCompareFunc instead of a #GCompareDataFunc as the compare function.
Since: 2.14

parameter.name: iter_cmp
parameter.parameter_description: the #GSequenceItercompare used to compare iterators in the sequence. It is called with two iterators pointing into @seq. It should return 0 if the iterators are equal, a negative value if the first iterator comes before the second, and a positive value if the second iterator comes before the first.

function.return: a #GSequenceIter pointing to the new item

function.name: g_sequence_iter_compare
function.description:
Returns a negative number if @a comes before @b, 0 if they are equal, and a positive number if @a comes after @b.
The @a and @b iterators must point into the same sequence.
Since: 2.14
function.return: A negative number if @a comes before @b, 0 if they are equal, and a positive number if @a comes after @b.

function.name: g_sequence_iter_get_position
function.description:
Returns the position of @iter
Since: 2.14
function.return: the position of @iter

function.name: g_sequence_iter_get_sequence
function.description:
Returns the #GSequence that @iter points into.
Since: 2.14
function.return: the #GSequence that @iter points into.

function.name: g_sequence_iter_is_begin
function.description:
Returns whether @iter is the begin iterator
Since: 2.14
function.return: whether @iter is the begin iterator

function.name: g_sequence_iter_is_end
function.description:
Returns whether @iter is the end iterator
Since: 2.14
function.return: Whether @iter is the end iterator.

function.name: g_sequence_iter_move
function.description:
Returns the #GSequenceIter which is @delta positions away from @iter. If @iter is closer than -@delta positions to the beginning of the sequence, the begin iterator is returned. If @iter is closer than @delta positions to the end of the sequence, the end iterator is returned.
Since: 2.14

parameter.name: delta
parameter.parameter_description: A positive or negative number indicating how many positions away from @iter the returned #GSequenceIter will be.

function.return: a #GSequenceIter which is @delta positions away from @iter.

function.name: g_sequence_iter_next
function.return: a #GSequenceIter pointing to the next position after @iter.

function.name: g_sequence_iter_prev
function.return: a #GSequenceIter pointing to the previous position before @iter.

function.name: g_sequence_lookup
function.description:
Returns an iterator pointing to the position of the first item found equal to @data according to @cmp_func and @cmp_data. If more than one item is equal, it is not guaranteed that it is the first which is returned. In that case, you can use g_sequence_iter_next() and g_sequence_iter_prev() to get others.
Since: 2.28

parameter.name: cmp_func
parameter.parameter_description: the #GCompareDataFunc used to compare items in the sequence. It is called with two items of the @seq and @user_data. It should return 0 if the items are equal, a negative value if the first item comes before the second, and a positive value if the second item comes before the first.

function.return: an #GSequenceIter pointing to the position of the first item found equal to @data according to @cmp_func and @cmp_data.

function.name: g_sequence_lookup_iter
function.description:
Like g_sequence_lookup(), but uses a #GSequenceIterCompareFunc instead of a #GCompareDataFunc as the compare function.
Since: 2.28

parameter.name: iter_cmp
parameter.parameter_description: the #GSequenceIterCompare function used to compare iterators in the sequence. It is called with two iterators pointing into @seq. It should return 0 if the iterators are equal, a negative value if the first iterator comes before the second, and a positive value if the second iterator comes before the first.

function.return: an #GSequenceIter pointing to the position of the first item found equal to @data according to @cmp_func and @cmp_data.

function.name: g_sequence_move
function.description:
Moves the item pointed to by @src to the position indicated by @dest. After calling this function @dest will point to the position immediately after @src. It is allowed for @src and @dest to point into different sequences.
Since: 2.14

parameter.name: src
parameter.parameter_description: a #GSequenceIter pointing to the item to move

parameter.name: dest
parameter.parameter_description: a #GSequenceIter pointing to the position to which the item is moved.

function.name: g_sequence_move_range
function.description:
Inserts the (@begin, @end) range at the destination pointed to by ptr. The @begin and @end iters must point into the same sequence. It is allowed for @dest to point to a different sequence than the one pointed into by @begin and @end.
If @dest is NULL, the range indicated by @begin and @end is removed from the sequence. If @dest iter points to a place within the (@begin, @end) range, the range does not move.
Since: 2.14

function.name: g_sequence_new
function.description:
Creates a new GSequence. The @data_destroy function, if non-%NULL will be called on all items when the sequence is destroyed and on items that are removed from the sequence.
Since: 2.14
function.return: a new #GSequence

function.name: g_sequence_prepend
function.description:
Adds a new item to the front of @seq
Since: 2.14

parameter.name: data
parameter.parameter_description: the data for the new item

function.return: an iterator pointing to the new item

function.name: g_sequence_range_get_midpoint
function.description:
Finds an iterator somewhere in the range (@begin, @end). This iterator will be close to the middle of the range, but is not guaranteed to be <emphasis>exactly</emphasis> in the middle.
The @begin and @end iterators must both point to the same sequence and @begin must come before or be equal to @end in the sequence.
Since: 2.14
function.return: A #GSequenceIter pointing somewhere in the (@begin, @end) range.

function.name: g_sequence_remove
function.description:
Removes the item pointed to by @iter. It is an error to pass the end iterator to this function.
If the sequnce has a data destroy function associated with it, this function is called on the data for the removed item.
Since: 2.14

function.name: g_sequence_remove_range
function.description:
Removes all items in the (@begin, @end) range.
If the sequence has a data destroy function associated with it, this function is called on the data for the removed items.
Since: 2.14

function.name: g_sequence_search
function.description:
Returns an iterator pointing to the position where @data would be inserted according to @cmp_func and @cmp_data.
If you are simply searching for an existing element of the sequence, consider using g_sequence_lookup().
Since: 2.14

parameter.name: cmp_func
parameter.parameter_description: the #GCompareDataFunc used to compare items in the sequence. It is called with two items of the @seq and @user_data. It should return 0 if the items are equal, a negative value if the first item comes before the second, and a positive value if the second item comes before the first.

function.return: an #GSequenceIter pointing to the position where @data would have been inserted according to @cmp_func and @cmp_data.

function.name: g_sequence_search_iter
function.description:
Like g_sequence_search(), but uses a #GSequenceIterCompareFunc instead of a #GCompareDataFunc as the compare function.
If you are simply searching for an existing element of the sequence, consider using g_sequence_lookup_iter().
Since: 2.14

parameter.name: iter_cmp
parameter.parameter_description: the #GSequenceIterCompare function used to compare iterators in the sequence. It is called with two iterators pointing into @seq. It should return 0 if the iterators are equal, a negative value if the first iterator comes before the second, and a positive value if the second iterator comes before the first.

function.return: a #GSequenceIter pointing to the position in @seq where @data would have been inserted according to @iter_cmp and @cmp_data.

function.name: g_sequence_set
function.description:
Changes the data for the item pointed to by @iter to be @data. If the sequence has a data destroy function associated with it, that function is called on the existing data that @iter pointed to.
Since: 2.14

function.name: g_sequence_sort
function.description:
Sorts @seq using @cmp_func.
Since: 2.14

parameter.name: cmp_func
parameter.parameter_description: the #GCompareDataFunc used to sort @seq. This function is passed two items of @seq and should return 0 if they are equal, a negative value if the first comes before the second, and a positive value if the second comes before the first.

function.name: g_sequence_sort_changed
function.description:
Moves the data pointed to a new position as indicated by @cmp_func. This function should be called for items in a sequence already sorted according to @cmp_func whenever some aspect of an item changes so that @cmp_func may return different values for that item.
Since: 2.14

parameter.name: cmp_func
parameter.parameter_description: the #GCompareDataFunc used to compare items in the sequence. It is called with two items of the @seq and @user_data. It should return 0 if the items are equal, a negative value if the first item comes before the second, and a positive value if the second item comes before the first.

function.name: g_sequence_sort_changed_iter
function.description:
Like g_sequence_sort_changed(), but uses a #GSequenceIterCompareFunc instead of a #GCompareDataFunc as the compare function.
Since: 2.14

parameter.name: iter_cmp
parameter.parameter_description: the #GSequenceItercompare used to compare iterators in the sequence. It is called with two iterators pointing into @seq. It should return 0 if the iterators are equal, a negative value if the first iterator comes before the second, and a positive value if the second iterator comes before the first.

function.name: g_sequence_sort_iter
function.description:
Like g_sequence_sort(), but uses a #GSequenceIterCompareFunc instead of a GCompareDataFunc as the compare function
Since: 2.14

parameter.name: cmp_func
parameter.parameter_description: the #GSequenceItercompare used to compare iterators in the sequence. It is called with two iterators pointing into @seq. It should return 0 if the iterators are equal, a negative value if the first iterator comes before the second, and a positive value if the second iterator comes before the first.

function.name: g_sequence_swap
function.description:
Swaps the items pointed to by @a and @b. It is allowed for @a and @b to point into difference sequences.
Since: 2.14

function.name: g_set_application_name
function.description:
Sets a human-readable name for the application. This name should be localized if possible, and is intended for display to the user. Contrast with g_set_prgname(), which sets a non-localized name. g_set_prgname() will be called automatically by gtk_init(), but g_set_application_name() will not.
Note that for thread safety reasons, this function can only be called once.
The application name will be used in contexts such as error messages, or when displaying an application's name in the task list.
Since: 2.2

function.name: g_set_error
function.description: Does nothing if @err is %NULL; if @err is non-%NULL, then *@err must be %NULL. A new #GError is created and assigned to *@err.

parameter.name: err
parameter.parameter_description: a return location for a #GError, or %NULL

function.name: g_set_error_literal
function.description:
Does nothing if @err is %NULL; if @err is non-%NULL, then *@err must be %NULL. A new #GError is created and assigned to *@err. Unlike g_set_error(), @message is not a printf()-style format string. Use this function if @message contains text you don't have control over, that could include printf() escape sequences.
Since: 2.18

parameter.name: err
parameter.parameter_description: a return location for a #GError, or %NULL

function.name: g_set_prgname
function.description: Sets the name of the program. This name should <emphasis>not</emphasis> be localized, contrast with g_set_application_name(). Note that for thread-safety reasons this function can only be called once.

function.name: g_setenv
function.description:
Sets an environment variable. Both the variable's name and value should be in the GLib file name encoding. On UNIX, this means that they can be any sequence of bytes. On Windows, they should be in UTF-8.
Note that on some systems, when variables are overwritten, the memory used for the previous variables and its value isn't reclaimed.
Since: 2.4

parameter.name: variable
parameter.parameter_description: the environment variable to set, must not contain '='.

parameter.name: value
parameter.parameter_description: the value for to set the variable to.

parameter.name: overwrite
parameter.parameter_description: whether to change the variable if it already exists.

function.return: %FALSE if the environment variable couldn't be set.

function.name: g_shell_parse_argv
function.description: Parses a command line into an argument vector, in much the same way the shell would, but without many of the expansions the shell would perform (variable expansion, globs, operators, filename expansion, etc. are not supported). The results are defined to be the same as those you would get from a UNIX98 /bin/sh, as long as the input contains none of the unsupported shell expansions. If the input does contain such expansions, they are passed through literally. Possible errors are those from the #G_SHELL_ERROR domain. Free the returned vector with g_strfreev().

parameter.name: argcp
parameter.parameter_description: return location for number of args

parameter.name: argvp
parameter.parameter_description: return location for array of args

function.return: %TRUE on success, %FALSE if error set

function.name: g_shell_quote
function.description: Quotes a string so that the shell (/bin/sh) will interpret the quoted string to mean @unquoted_string. If you pass a filename to the shell, for example, you should first quote it with this function. The return value must be freed with g_free(). The quoting style used is undefined (single or double quotes may be used).
function.return: quoted string

function.name: g_shell_unquote
function.description:
Unquotes a string as the shell (/bin/sh) would. Only handles quotes; if a string contains file globs, arithmetic operators, variables, backticks, redirections, or other special-to-the-shell features, the result will be different from the result a real shell would produce (the variables, backticks, etc. will be passed through literally instead of being expanded). This function is guaranteed to succeed if applied to the result of g_shell_quote(). If it fails, it returns %NULL and sets the error. The @quoted_string need not actually contain quoted or escaped text; g_shell_unquote() simply goes through the string and unquotes/unescapes anything that the shell would. Both single and double quotes are handled, as are escapes including escaped newlines. The return value must be freed with g_free(). Possible errors are in the #G_SHELL_ERROR domain.
Shell quoting rules are a bit strange. Single quotes preserve the literal string exactly. escape sequences are not allowed; not even \' - if you want a ' in the quoted text, you have to do something like 'foo'\''bar'. Double quotes allow $, `, ", \, and newline to be escaped with backslash. Otherwise double quotes preserve things literally.
function.return: an unquoted string

function.name: g_slist_alloc
function.description: Allocates space for one #GSList element. It is called by the g_slist_append(), g_slist_prepend(), g_slist_insert() and g_slist_insert_sorted() functions and so is rarely used on its own.
function.return: a pointer to the newly-allocated #GSList element.

function.name: g_slist_append

parameter.name: data
parameter.parameter_description: the data for the new element

function.return: the new start of the #GSList

function.name: g_slist_concat
function.description: Adds the second #GSList onto the end of the first #GSList. Note that the elements of the second #GSList are not copied. They are used directly.

parameter.name: list2
parameter.parameter_description: the #GSList to add to the end of the first #GSList

function.return: the start of the new #GSList

function.name: g_slist_copy
function.description:
Copies a #GSList.
<note><para> Note that this is a "shallow" copy. If the list elements consist of pointers to data, the pointers are copied but the actual data isn't. </para></note>
function.return: a copy of @list

function.name: g_slist_delete_link
function.description: Removes the node link_ from the list and frees it. Compare this to g_slist_remove_link() which removes the node without freeing it.
function.return: the new head of @list

function.name: g_slist_find
function.description: Finds the element in a #GSList which contains the given data.
function.return: the found #GSList element, or %NULL if it is not found

function.name: g_slist_find_custom
function.description: Finds an element in a #GSList, using a supplied function to find the desired element. It iterates over the list, calling the given function which should return 0 when the desired element is found. The function takes two #gconstpointer arguments, the #GSList element's data as the first argument and the given user data.

parameter.name: data
parameter.parameter_description: user data passed to the function

parameter.name: func
parameter.parameter_description: the function to call for each element. It should return 0 when the desired element is found

function.return: the found #GSList element, or %NULL if it is not found

function.name: g_slist_foreach
function.description: Calls a function for each element of a #GSList.

parameter.name: func
parameter.parameter_description: the function to call with each element's data

parameter.name: user_data
parameter.parameter_description: user data to pass to the function

function.name: g_slist_free
function.description:
Frees all of the memory used by a #GSList. The freed elements are returned to the slice allocator.
<note><para> If list elements contain dynamically-allocated memory, you should either use g_slist_free_full() or free them manually first. </para></note>

function.name: g_slist_free1
function.description:
A macro which does the same as g_slist_free_1().
Since: 2.10

function.name: g_slist_free_1
function.description: Frees one #GSList element. It is usually used after g_slist_remove_link().

function.name: g_slist_free_full
function.description:
Convenience method, which frees all the memory used by a #GSList, and calls the specified destroy function on every element's data.
Since: 2.28

parameter.name: free_func
parameter.parameter_description: the function to be called to free each element's data

function.name: g_slist_index
function.description: Gets the position of the element containing the given data (starting from 0).
function.return: the index of the element containing the data, or -1 if the data is not found

function.name: g_slist_insert
function.description: Inserts a new element into the list at the given position.

parameter.name: data
parameter.parameter_description: the data for the new element

parameter.name: position
parameter.parameter_description: the position to insert the element. If this is negative, or is larger than the number of elements in the list, the new element is added on to the end of the list.

function.return: the new start of the #GSList

function.name: g_slist_insert_before
function.description: Inserts a node before @sibling containing @data.

parameter.name: data
parameter.parameter_description: data to put in the newly-inserted node

function.return: the new head of the list.

function.name: g_slist_insert_sorted
function.description: Inserts a new element into the list, using the given comparison function to determine its position.

parameter.name: data
parameter.parameter_description: the data for the new element

parameter.name: func
parameter.parameter_description: the function to compare elements in the list. It should return a number > 0 if the first parameter comes after the second parameter in the sort order.

function.return: the new start of the #GSList

function.name: g_slist_insert_sorted_with_data
function.description:
Inserts a new element into the list, using the given comparison function to determine its position.
Since: 2.10

parameter.name: data
parameter.parameter_description: the data for the new element

parameter.name: func
parameter.parameter_description: the function to compare elements in the list. It should return a number > 0 if the first parameter comes after the second parameter in the sort order.

parameter.name: user_data
parameter.parameter_description: data to pass to comparison function

function.return: the new start of the #GSList

function.name: g_slist_last
function.description:
Gets the last element in a #GSList.
<note><para> This function iterates over the whole list. </para></note>
function.return: the last element in the #GSList, or %NULL if the #GSList has no elements

function.name: g_slist_length
function.description:
Gets the number of elements in a #GSList.
<note><para> This function iterates over the whole list to count its elements. </para></note>
function.return: the number of elements in the #GSList

function.name: g_slist_next
function.description: A convenience macro to get the next element in a #GSList.
function.return: the next element, or %NULL if there are no more elements.

function.name: g_slist_nth
function.description: Gets the element at the given position in a #GSList.

parameter.name: n
parameter.parameter_description: the position of the element, counting from 0

function.return: the element, or %NULL if the position is off the end of the #GSList

function.name: g_slist_nth_data
function.description: Gets the data of the element at the given position.
function.return: the element's data, or %NULL if the position is off the end of the #GSList

function.name: g_slist_pop_allocator
function.description:
Restores the previous #GAllocator, used when allocating #GSList elements.
Note that this function is not available if GLib has been compiled with <option>--disable-mem-pools</option>
Deprecated: 2.10: It does nothing, since #GSList has been converted to the <link linkend="glib-Memory-Slices">slice allocator</link>

function.name: g_slist_position
function.description: Gets the position of the given element in the #GSList (starting from 0).
function.return: the position of the element in the #GSList, or -1 if the element is not found

function.name: g_slist_prepend

parameter.name: data
parameter.parameter_description: the data for the new element

function.return: the new start of the #GSList

function.name: g_slist_push_allocator
function.description:
Sets the allocator to use to allocate #GSList elements. Use g_slist_pop_allocator() to restore the previous allocator.
Note that this function is not available if GLib has been compiled with <option>--disable-mem-pools</option>
Deprecated: 2.10: It does nothing, since #GSList has been converted to the <link linkend="glib-Memory-Slices">slice allocator</link>

parameter.name: dummy
parameter.parameter_description: the #GAllocator to use when allocating #GSList elements.

function.name: g_slist_remove
function.description: Removes an element from a #GSList. If two elements contain the same data, only the first is removed. If none of the elements contain the data, the #GSList is unchanged.

parameter.name: data
parameter.parameter_description: the data of the element to remove

function.return: the new start of the #GSList

function.name: g_slist_remove_all
function.description: Removes all list nodes with data equal to @data. Returns the new head of the list. Contrast with g_slist_remove() which removes only the first node matching the given data.
function.return: new head of @list

function.name: g_slist_remove_link
function.description: Removes an element from a #GSList, without freeing the element. The removed element's next link is set to %NULL, so that it becomes a self-contained list with one element.
function.return: the new start of the #GSList, without the element

function.name: g_slist_reverse
function.description: Reverses a #GSList.
function.return: the start of the reversed #GSList

function.name: g_slist_sort
function.description: Sorts a #GSList using the given comparison function.

parameter.name: compare_func
parameter.parameter_description: the comparison function used to sort the #GSList. This function is passed the data from 2 elements of the #GSList and should return 0 if they are equal, a negative value if the first element comes before the second, or a positive value if the first element comes after the second.

function.return: the start of the sorted #GSList

function.name: g_slist_sort_with_data
function.description: Like g_slist_sort(), but the sort function accepts a user data argument.

parameter.name: user_data
parameter.parameter_description: data to pass to comparison function

function.return: new head of the list

function.name: g_snprintf
function.description:
A safer form of the standard sprintf() function. The output is guaranteed to not exceed @n characters (including the terminating nul character), so it is easy to ensure that a buffer overflow cannot occur.
See also g_strdup_printf().
In versions of GLib prior to 1.2.3, this function may return -1 if the output was truncated, and the truncated string may not be nul-terminated. In versions prior to 1.3.12, this function returns the length of the output string.
The return value of g_snprintf() conforms to the snprintf() function as standardized in ISO C99. Note that this is different from traditional snprintf(), which returns the length of the output string.
The format string may contain positional parameters, as specified in the Single Unix Specification.

parameter.name: string
parameter.parameter_description: the buffer to hold the output.

parameter.name: n
parameter.parameter_description: the maximum number of bytes to produce (including the terminating nul character).

parameter.name: format
parameter.parameter_description: a standard printf() format string, but notice <link linkend="string-precision">string precision pitfalls</link>.

parameter.name: Varargs
parameter.parameter_description: the arguments to insert in the output.

function.return: the number of bytes which would be produced if the buffer was large enough.

function.name: g_source_add_child_source
function.description:
Adds @child_source to @source as a "polled" source; when @source is added to a #GMainContext, @child_source will be automatically added with the same priority, when @child_source is triggered, it will cause @source to dispatch (in addition to calling its own callback), and when @source is destroyed, it will destroy @child_source as well. (@source will also still be dispatched if its own prepare/check functions indicate that it is ready.)
If you don't need @child_source to do anything on its own when it triggers, you can call g_source_set_dummy_callback() on it to set a callback that does nothing (except return %TRUE if appropriate).
@source will hold a reference on @child_source while @child_source is attached to it.
Since: 2.28

function.name: g_source_add_poll
function.description: Adds a file descriptor to the set of file descriptors polled for this source. This is usually combined with g_source_new() to add an event source. The event source's check function will typically test the @revents field in the #GPollFD struct and return %TRUE if events need to be processed.

parameter.name: fd
parameter.parameter_description: a #GPollFD structure holding information about a file descriptor to watch.

function.name: g_source_attach
function.description: Adds a #GSource to a @context so that it will be executed within that context. Remove it by calling g_source_destroy().

parameter.name: context
parameter.parameter_description: a #GMainContext (if %NULL, the default context will be used)

function.return: the ID (greater than 0) for the source within the #GMainContext.

function.name: g_source_destroy
function.description: Removes a source from its #GMainContext, if any, and mark it as destroyed. The source cannot be subsequently added to another context.

function.name: g_source_get_can_recurse
function.description: Checks whether a source is allowed to be called recursively. see g_source_set_can_recurse().
function.return: whether recursion is allowed.

function.name: g_source_get_context
function.description: Gets the #GMainContext with which the source is associated. Calling this function on a destroyed source is an error.
function.return: the #GMainContext with which the source is associated, or %NULL if the context has not yet been added to a source.

function.name: g_source_get_current_time
function.description:
Gets the "current time" to be used when checking this source. The advantage of calling this function over calling g_get_current_time() directly is that when checking multiple sources, GLib can cache a single value instead of having to repeatedly get the system time.
Deprecated: 2.28: use g_source_get_time() instead

parameter.name: timeval
parameter.parameter_description: #GTimeVal structure in which to store current time.

function.name: g_source_get_id
function.description: Returns the numeric ID for a particular source. The ID of a source is a positive integer which is unique within a particular main loop context. The reverse mapping from ID to source is done by g_main_context_find_source_by_id().
function.return: the ID (greater than 0) for the source

function.name: g_source_get_name
function.description:
Gets a name for the source, used in debugging and profiling. The name may be #NULL if it has never been set with g_source_set_name().
Since: 2.26
function.return: the name of the source

function.name: g_source_get_priority
function.description: Gets the priority of a source.
function.return: the priority of the source

function.name: g_source_get_time
function.description:
Gets the time to be used when checking this source. The advantage of calling this function over calling g_get_monotonic_time() directly is that when checking multiple sources, GLib can cache a single value instead of having to repeatedly get the system monotonic time.
The time here is the system monotonic time, if available, or some other reasonable alternative otherwise. See g_get_monotonic_time().
Since: 2.28
function.return: the monotonic time in microseconds

function.name: g_source_is_destroyed
function.return: %TRUE if the source has been destroyed

function.name: g_source_new
function.description:
Creates a new #GSource structure. The size is specified to allow creating structures derived from #GSource that contain additional data. The size passed in must be at least <literal>sizeof (GSource)</literal>.
The source will not initially be associated with any #GMainContext and must be added to one with g_source_attach() before it will be executed.

parameter.name: source_funcs
parameter.parameter_description: structure containing functions that implement the sources behavior.

parameter.name: struct_size
parameter.parameter_description: size of the #GSource structure to create.

function.return: the newly-created #GSource.

function.name: g_source_ref
function.description: Increases the reference count on a source by one.
function.return: @source

function.name: g_source_remove
function.description:
Removes the source with the given id from the default main context. The id of a #GSource is given by g_source_get_id(), or will be returned by the functions g_source_attach(), g_idle_add(), g_idle_add_full(), g_timeout_add(), g_timeout_add_full(), g_child_watch_add(), g_child_watch_add_full(), g_io_add_watch(), and g_io_add_watch_full().
See also g_source_destroy(). You must use g_source_destroy() for sources added to a non-default main context.

parameter.name: tag
parameter.parameter_description: the ID of the source to remove.

function.return: %TRUE if the source was found and removed.

function.name: g_source_remove_by_funcs_user_data
function.description: Removes a source from the default main loop context given the source functions and user data. If multiple sources exist with the same source functions and user data, only one will be destroyed.

parameter.name: user_data
parameter.parameter_description: the user data for the callback

function.return: %TRUE if a source was found and removed.

function.name: g_source_remove_by_user_data
function.description: Removes a source from the default main loop context given the user data for the callback. If multiple sources exist with the same user data, only one will be destroyed.
function.return: %TRUE if a source was found and removed.

function.name: g_source_remove_child_source
function.description:
Detaches @child_source from @source and destroys it.
Since: 2.28

function.name: g_source_remove_poll
function.description: Removes a file descriptor from the set of file descriptors polled for this source.

parameter.name: fd
parameter.parameter_description: a #GPollFD structure previously passed to g_source_add_poll().

function.name: g_source_set_callback
function.description:
Sets the callback function for a source. The callback for a source is called from the source's dispatch function.
The exact type of @func depends on the type of source; ie. you should not count on @func being called with @data as its first parameter.
Typically, you won't use this function. Instead use functions specific to the type of source you are using.

parameter.name: data
parameter.parameter_description: the data to pass to callback function

parameter.name: notify
parameter.parameter_description: a function to call when @data is no longer in use, or %NULL.

function.name: g_source_set_callback_indirect
function.description: Sets the callback function storing the data as a refcounted callback "object". This is used internally. Note that calling g_source_set_callback_indirect() assumes an initial reference count on @callback_data, and thus @callback_funcs->unref will eventually be called once more than @callback_funcs->ref.

parameter.name: callback_funcs
parameter.parameter_description: functions for reference counting @callback_data and getting the callback and data

function.name: g_source_set_can_recurse
function.description: Sets whether a source can be called recursively. If @can_recurse is %TRUE, then while the source is being dispatched then this source will be processed normally. Otherwise, all processing of this source is blocked until the dispatch function returns.

parameter.name: can_recurse
parameter.parameter_description: whether recursion is allowed for this source

function.name: g_source_set_funcs
function.description:
Sets the source functions (can be used to override default implementations) of an unattached source.
Since: 2.12

function.name: g_source_set_name
function.description:
Sets a name for the source, used in debugging and profiling. The name defaults to #NULL.
The source name should describe in a human-readable way what the source does. For example, "X11 event queue" or "GTK+ repaint idle handler" or whatever it is.
It is permitted to call this function multiple times, but is not recommended due to the potential performance impact. For example, one could change the name in the "check" function of a #GSourceFuncs to include details like the event type in the source name.
Since: 2.26

function.name: g_source_set_name_by_id
function.description:
Sets the name of a source using its ID.
This is a convenience utility to set source names from the return value of g_idle_add(), g_timeout_add(), etc.
Since: 2.26

function.name: g_source_set_priority
function.description: Sets the priority of a source. While the main loop is being run, a source will be dispatched if it is ready to be dispatched and no sources at a higher (numerically smaller) priority are ready to be dispatched.

function.name: g_source_unref
function.description: Decreases the reference count of a source by one. If the resulting reference count is zero the source and associated memory will be destroyed.

function.name: g_spawn_async
function.description:
See g_spawn_async_with_pipes() for a full description; this function simply calls the g_spawn_async_with_pipes() without any pipes.
You should call g_spawn_close_pid() on the returned child process reference when you don't need it any more.
<note><para> If you are writing a GTK+ application, and the program you are spawning is a graphical application, too, then you may want to use gdk_spawn_on_screen() instead to ensure that the spawned program opens its windows on the right screen. </para></note>
<note><para> Note that the returned @child_pid on Windows is a handle to the child process and not its identifier. Process handles and process identifiers are different concepts on Windows. </para></note>

parameter.name: working_directory
parameter.parameter_description: child's current working directory, or %NULL to inherit parent's

parameter.name: envp
parameter.parameter_description: child's environment, or %NULL to inherit parent's

parameter.name: child_setup
parameter.parameter_description: function to run in the child just before exec()

parameter.name: child_pid
parameter.parameter_description: return location for child process reference, or %NULL

function.return: %TRUE on success, %FALSE if error is set

function.name: g_spawn_async_with_pipes
function.description:
Executes a child program asynchronously (your program will not block waiting for the child to exit). The child program is specified by the only argument that must be provided, @argv. @argv should be a %NULL-terminated array of strings, to be passed as the argument vector for the child. The first string in @argv is of course the name of the program to execute. By default, the name of the program must be a full path; the <envar>PATH</envar> shell variable will only be searched if you pass the %G_SPAWN_SEARCH_PATH flag.
On Windows, note that all the string or string vector arguments to this function and the other g_spawn*() functions are in UTF-8, the GLib file name encoding. Unicode characters that are not part of the system codepage passed in these arguments will be correctly available in the spawned program only if it uses wide character API to retrieve its command line. For C programs built with Microsoft's tools it is enough to make the program have a wmain() instead of main(). wmain() has a wide character argument vector as parameter.
At least currently, mingw doesn't support wmain(), so if you use mingw to develop the spawned program, it will have to call the undocumented function __wgetmainargs() to get the wide character argument vector and environment. See gspawn-win32-helper.c in the GLib sources or init.c in the mingw runtime sources for a prototype for that function. Alternatively, you can retrieve the Win32 system level wide character command line passed to the spawned program using the GetCommandLineW() function.
On Windows the low-level child process creation API <function>CreateProcess()</function> doesn't use argument vectors, but a command line. The C runtime library's <function>spawn*()</function> family of functions (which g_spawn_async_with_pipes() eventually calls) paste the argument vector elements together into a command line, and the C runtime startup code does a corresponding reconstruction of an argument vector from the command line, to be passed to main(). Complications arise when you have argument vector elements that contain spaces of double quotes. The <function>spawn*()</function> functions don't do any quoting or escaping, but on the other hand the startup code does do unquoting and unescaping in order to enable receiving arguments with embedded spaces or double quotes. To work around this asymmetry, g_spawn_async_with_pipes() will do quoting and escaping on argument vector elements that need it before calling the C runtime spawn() function.
The returned @child_pid on Windows is a handle to the child process, not its identifier. Process handles and process identifiers are different concepts on Windows.
@envp is a %NULL-terminated array of strings, where each string has the form <literal>KEY=VALUE</literal>. This will become the child's environment. If @envp is %NULL, the child inherits its parent's environment.
@flags should be the bitwise OR of any flags you want to affect the function's behaviour. The %G_SPAWN_DO_NOT_REAP_CHILD means that the child will not automatically be reaped; you must use a #GChildWatch source to be notified about the death of the child process. Eventually you must call g_spawn_close_pid() on the @child_pid, in order to free resources which may be associated with the child process. (On Unix, using a #GChildWatch source is equivalent to calling waitpid() or handling the %SIGCHLD signal manually. On Windows, calling g_spawn_close_pid() is equivalent to calling CloseHandle() on the process handle returned in @child_pid).
%G_SPAWN_LEAVE_DESCRIPTORS_OPEN means that the parent's open file descriptors will be inherited by the child; otherwise all descriptors except stdin/stdout/stderr will be closed before calling exec() in the child. %G_SPAWN_SEARCH_PATH means that <literal>argv[0]</literal> need not be an absolute path, it will be looked for in the user's <envar>PATH</envar>. %G_SPAWN_STDOUT_TO_DEV_NULL means that the child's standard output will be discarded, instead of going to the same location as the parent's standard output. If you use this flag, @standard_output must be %NULL. %G_SPAWN_STDERR_TO_DEV_NULL means that the child's standard error will be discarded, instead of going to the same location as the parent's standard error. If you use this flag, @standard_error must be %NULL. %G_SPAWN_CHILD_INHERITS_STDIN means that the child will inherit the parent's standard input (by default, the child's standard input is attached to /dev/null). If you use this flag, @standard_input must be %NULL. %G_SPAWN_FILE_AND_ARGV_ZERO means that the first element of @argv is the file to execute, while the remaining elements are the actual argument vector to pass to the file. Normally g_spawn_async_with_pipes() uses @argv[0] as the file to execute, and passes all of @argv to the child.
@child_setup and @user_data are a function and user data.
